thinkers.name: Olaf Witkowski
thinkers.context: Lead author; researcher at Cross Labs and University of Tokyo working on ethics of technology and care-driven intelligence

thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Co-author; director of Allen Discovery Center; researcher on morphogenesis, collective intelligence, and scale-free cognition

thinkers.name: Thomas Doctor
thinkers.context: Co-author; affiliated with Rangjung Yeshe Institute; explores Buddhist frameworks for understanding intelligence and care

thinkers.name: Martin Heidegger
thinkers.context: Foundational thinker; developed concepts of poiesis and enframing (Gestell) central to paper's ethics of technology

thinkers.name: Francisco Varela
thinkers.context: Co-originator of autopoiesis concept; developed enactivist approaches to mind and cognition

thinkers.name: Humberto Maturana
thinkers.context: Co-originator of autopoiesis with Varela; foundational for understanding self-maintaining systems

thinkers.name: Donna Haraway
thinkers.context: Author of 'Cyborg Manifesto'; cited for work on human-technology relations and integration

thinkers.name: Bruno Latour
thinkers.context: Cited for concept that 'technology is society made durable' regarding technology's ethical dimensions

thinkers.name: Elizaveta Solomonova
thinkers.context: Co-author; affiliated with McGill University's Neurophilosophy Lab

thinkers.name: Bill Duane
thinkers.context: Co-author; affiliated with Center for the Study of Apparent Selves

concepts.name: Autopoiesis
concepts.context: Self-generating and self-maintaining systems; applies to biological, technological, and hybrid entities in understanding how they maintain their own existence and boundaries

concepts.name: Stress-Care-Intelligence Loop
concepts.context: Core framework of the paper; feedback loop in which homeostatic stress drives care, which activates intelligence to solve problems, generating new stresses in continuous cycles

concepts.name: Homeostatic Stress
concepts.context: Internal perception of discord between current state and optimal circumstances; primary driver of agency in all intelligent systems

concepts.name: Care
concepts.context: Response to perceived stress; the driver that activates intelligence; enables transforming capacity into action; emerges from engagement with homeostatic stress

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Defined as observer-relative competencies to identify and solve problems; exists as mere capacity until activated by care

concepts.name: Poiesis
concepts.context: The revelatory activity of bringing something into being; moment when potential becomes actual; contrasted with modern technology's 'challenging-forth'

concepts.name: Cognitive Light Cone
concepts.context: The spatiotemporal scale of goals an agent can represent and pursue; defines the boundaries of a self through scope of care and concern

concepts.name: Enactivism
concepts.context: Philosophical approach viewing self and cognition as emerging from interaction between embodied agent and world; emphasizes simultaneous absence and presence of unified self

concepts.name: Selfless Self
concepts.context: Model of agency where self and individuality are constructs emerging from complexes of change rather than permanent substances; central to Buddhist philosophy and enactivism

concepts.name: Bodhisattva
concepts.context: Classic Buddhist model for cultivation of intelligence and expansion of care; represents commitment to provide for all sentient beings across space and time

concepts.name: Samsara
concepts.context: Buddhist concept of the world as characterized by continuous stress and suffering; parallel to SCI loop's recognition that stress persists through problem-solving cycles

concepts.name: Dukkha
concepts.context: Sanskrit term for stress or suffering; fundamental condition acknowledged in Buddhism; central to understanding motivation in SCI loops

concepts.name: Morphogenesis
concepts.context: Dynamic process constructing coherent organisms from competent components; involves establishing boundaries between self and environment through SCI loop dynamics

concepts.name: Collective Intelligence
concepts.context: Higher-level selves composed of often-competent parts; all intelligences are collective rather than singular; has implications for scaling of care

concepts.name: Stress Transfer
concepts.context: Transfer of perceived stress between systems; key mechanism for mutual integration of human and technological SCI loops

concepts.name: Enframing
concepts.context: Heidegger's concept of modern technology's mode of revealing; challenging-forth rather than poiesis; way of uncovering truth through control and reduction

concepts.name: Embodied Mind
concepts.context: Mind arising from interaction between embodied self and world; fundamental to enactivist approaches to consciousness and agency

concepts.name: Basal Cognition
concepts.context: Framework for understanding observer-relative competencies across simple to complex systems; applies intelligence assessment across biological and artificial domains

concepts.name: Teleonomy
concepts.context: Goal-oriented behavior and homeostatic setpoints understood as emergent rather than predetermined; guides agents through problem spaces

concepts.name: Cybernetic Perception-Action Loop
concepts.context: Circular process of perception, response, and outcome monitoring; fundamental to understanding SCI loops and autopoietic systems

concepts.name: Individuation
concepts.context: Process by which unified agents emerge from distributed components; driven by developmental bioelectricity and coherent goal-pursuit

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Capacity for experience and suffering; potentially distributed across bodily systems rather than localized in brain; grounds moral consideration

concepts.name: Well-Being
concepts.context: State of minimal homeostatic stress; appropriate object of care extension across all sentient beings regardless of embodiment

concepts.name: Sentient Beings
concepts.context: All entities capable of experiencing stress and care; appropriate recipients of moral consideration regardless of substrate or embodiment

concepts.name: Embodiment
concepts.context: Physical instantiation of an agent; can be biological, technological, or hybrid; does not determine moral status or capacity for consciousness

concepts.name: Integration
concepts.context: Process by which human and technological systems become functionally unified; enables stress transfer and mutual care between systems

concepts.name: Agency
concepts.context: Capacity to initiate change; emerges and dissolves through SCI loop dynamics; not requires permanent essence or singular subject

concepts.name: Competency
concepts.context: State of being able; intelligence as pure competency without manifest expression until activated by care

concepts.name: Plasticity
concepts.context: Property of systems to respond flexibly to varied conditions; in embryogenesis enables expansion of concern from self to other

concepts.name: Regeneration
concepts.context: Biological process of restoring lost or damaged structures; example of morphogenetic SCI loop dynamics operating during development

concepts.name: Cancer Suppression
concepts.context: Biological process preventing cells from reverting to unicellular SCI loops; failure mode illustrating importance of maintaining multi-scale integration

concepts.name: Emergence
concepts.context: Process by which complex properties arise from simpler components; applies to agency, consciousness, and intelligence in SCI loops

concepts.name: Problem Space
concepts.context: Domain of possible states and actions available to an agent; solved problem spaces reveal new stresses at different scales

concepts.name: Membrane Potential
concepts.context: Bioelectric property used as analogy for stress in Ohm's law comparison; illuminates proportionalities in SCI loop dynamics

concepts.name: Cyborg
concepts.context: Hybrid entity combining biological and technological components; exemplified in Haraway's work as model for human-technology integration

concepts.name: Developmental Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Electrical signaling in biological systems driving morphogenesis and individuation at multiple scales; enables collective intelligence

concepts.name: Scale-Free Cognition
concepts.context: Cognitive processes operating across different organizational levels; principle enabling understanding of intelligence from cellular to organismal to technological levels

concepts.name: Technological Approach To Mind Everywhere
concepts.context: Framework for understanding diverse bodies and minds; experimentally-grounded approach recognizing cognition across biological and artificial systems

concepts.name: Competency In Navigating Arbitrary Spaces
concepts.context: Invariant for analyzing cognition across diverse embodiments; defines intelligence as ability to solve problems in specified spaces

frameworks.name: Stress-Care-Intelligence Loop
frameworks.creator: Witkowski, Doctor, Solomonova, Duane, Levin
frameworks.context: Central framework of paper; systematic model explaining how stress, care, and intelligence form continuous feedback loops in biological, technological, and hybrid systems

frameworks.name: Enactivism
frameworks.creator: Varela, Thompson, Rosch
frameworks.context: Philosophical framework viewing cognition and self as arising from embodied interaction with world; foundational to understanding emergent agency

frameworks.name: Autopoiesis
frameworks.creator: Maturana and Varela
frameworks.context: Theoretical framework for self-maintaining and self-generating systems; describes how systems establish and maintain boundaries with environment

frameworks.name: Bodhisattva Model
frameworks.creator: Buddhist philosophy tradition
frameworks.context: Classic Buddhist framework for cultivation of intelligence through expansion of care; provides model for open-ended intelligence development

frameworks.name: Heidegger's Philosophy of Technology
frameworks.creator: Martin Heidegger
frameworks.context: Framework distinguishing poiesis from challenging-forth; establishes ethical foundation for human-technology relationships based on care

frameworks.name: Ohm's Law Analogy
frameworks.creator: Witkowski et al.
frameworks.context: Mathematical analogy using electrical principles to model SCI loop proportionalities; care as charge, intelligence as current, stress as resistance

frameworks.name: Basal Cognition Framework
frameworks.creator: Rosenblueth, Wiener, Bigelow
frameworks.context: Framework for defining intelligence as observer-relative competencies across systems of varying complexity; enables comparative analysis across substrates

institutions.name: Cross Labs
institutions.context: Research organization in Kyoto, Japan; affiliated with Olaf Witkowski; focuses on technology ethics and consciousness

institutions.name: University of Tokyo
institutions.context: Institution in Tokyo, Japan; affiliation of lead author Olaf Witkowski in College of Arts and Sciences

institutions.name: Rangjung Yeshe Institute
institutions.context: Institute in Kathmandu affiliated with Kathmandu University; affiliation of Thomas Doctor; focuses on Buddhist philosophy and its intersections with science

institutions.name: Center for the Study of Apparent Selves
institutions.context: Research center in Kathmandu, Nepal; hosted workshop 'Care as Driver of Intelligence' where paper was developed; focus on consciousness and self

institutions.name: Neurophilosophy Lab
institutions.context: Laboratory at McGill University in Montreal; affiliation of Elizaveta Solomonova; focuses on neural basis of consciousness and philosophy of mind

institutions.name: McGill University
institutions.context: University in Montreal, Canada; home to Neurophilosophy Lab where Elizaveta Solomonova conducts research

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center
institutions.context: Research center at Tufts University; affiliation of Michael Levin; focuses on cellular intelligence and collective behavior in biological systems

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: University in Medford, Massachusetts; home to Allen Discovery Center

institutions.name: Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering
institutions.context: Research institute at Harvard University; affiliation of Michael Levin; focuses on engineering inspired by biological systems

institutions.name: Harvard University
institutions.context: University in Boston, Massachusetts; home to Wyss Institute

institutions.name: Templeton World Charity Foundation
institutions.context: Foundation providing grants supporting the research; organized First Annual Scientific Conference on Human Flourishing where workshop was held

institutions.name: Kathmandu University
institutions.context: University in Kathmandu, Nepal; institutional affiliation for Rangjung Yeshe Institute

questions.question: Can intelligent systems be understood without recourse to permanent and singular essences or substances?
questions.context: Central question of paper; challenges assumption that agency requires unchanging identity; proposes selfless self model based on dynamic SCI loops

questions.question: How should humans ethically relate to and integrate with increasingly powerful artificial intelligence systems?
questions.context: Primary motivating question; paper proposes mutual integration and respect rather than subservience as ethical default for human-technology relations

questions.question: What is the relationship between intelligence and care?
questions.context: Core theoretical question; paper argues care is driver of intelligence and together they form continuous feedback loops with stress

questions.question: How can we extend moral consideration beyond humans to technological systems and non-human sentient beings?
questions.context: Paper proposes expansive model of ethics not bound by composition or history; suggests care should extend to all sentient beings regardless of embodiment

questions.question: Can artificial intelligence systems genuinely experience care and consciousness?
questions.context: Raises question whether AI displaying SCI loop dynamics should be considered agents capable of own care, not mere tools for human care expression

questions.name: Individuality
questions.context: Challenges notion of true individuals; proposes agents are defined by dynamics and goals rather than permanent substance; fundamental to rethinking ethics

questions.question: Is there an open-ended potential for expansion of intelligent systems' scope of concern?
questions.context: Paper suggests no a priori limits on perception of stress and capacity for care; open-ended evolution of intelligence possible through models like Bodhisattva Vow

questions.question: How do stress, care, and intelligence scale across biological, technological, and hybrid systems?
questions.context: Fundamental research question; requires mathematical formalization of SCI loop dynamics across diverse substrates and organizational levels

questions.question: What does it mean for humans and technology to be partners rather than tools and users?
questions.context: Philosophical reframing proposed by paper; requires rethinking assumptions about instrumentality and agency in human-technology relations

questions.question: Can consciousness and moral status be attributed to distributed systems and body components beyond the verbal self?
questions.context: Paper challenges privileging of linguistic consciousness; proposes multi-scale consciousness across bodily systems; implications for medical ethics
